questions.question: How many ways can Marge assemble 6 identical math books, 12 identical English books, and 4 identical history books on her Shelf of Knowledge?
How many ways can 14 horses finish in a race if it is known that 7 of them will undoubtedly finish in the top 7 and the other 7 will finish in the bottom seven?

On a food menu for a hamburger, there are 3 different kinds of buns, 2 kinds of burgers, 4 kinds of toppings, and 3 kinds of vegetables. How many different hamburgers can you make if you choose exactly one kind from each category?
6. Ten friends want to sit at a round table. How many relative orders are there for them to sit at the table?

Julia has a circular bracelet. She has 5 blue beads, 3 pink beads, 4 white beads, and 1 black bead that she can put on the bracelet. Assuming she uses all the beads, how many different ways can she create her bracelet. (Note: It's considered to be the same bracelet if the relative order of the beads were reversed because that's the equivalent of flipping it over.)
Winfred puts $50 every month for 10 years into a retirement fund that earns 5% interest compounded monthly. How much money will he have at the end of the decade?
Simplify (x+3)<sup>2</sup> – (x+2)<sup>2</sup> + 4x<sup>3</sup> – 8x.
The sum of a 10-term arithmetic series with first term 27 is equal to 6(x<sub>10</sub>). What is the common difference of the series?
The yearly decay constant for alpacium-2015 is 0.28. If an initial sample contains 2,015 atoms, how many atoms remain in the sample after 4 years, rounded to the nearest atom?

A population of 100 rabbits grows continuously such that it triples every 5 years. After 7 years, a population of 100 falcons is introduced. This falcon population grows continuously such that it triples every 2 years. However, it also makes the rabbit population decrease continuously by 50 each year. After this introduction, how many years will it take for the falcon population to equal the rabbit population? Round your answer to the nearest thousandth.
Compute the variance of {2,2,3,5,7,11,15,18,20}.
Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The mode of a set does not have to be a member of that set
A set can have more outliers than non-outliers
The standard deviation of a set can be negative
Any set has a member with a z-score with a value of 0
The median of a data set will not change if we remove both a high and low outlier
questions.answer: The median of a data set will not change if we remove both a high and low outlier

questions.question: James is a bad scientist and wants to fabricate data about pine tree length to make it look approximately normal. If he has 300 trees in the sample with a maximum value of 127 meters and the average value is 103 meters tall, what is the best mean and standard deviation James can fib to make the data look normal?
What is the best measure of central tendency in the set {1,1,3,3,3,3,4,6,6,6,7,8,52}?
Desperate Danny is entering a lottery with 1,000 $5 tickets for sale, a $3,000 first-place prize and 3 $100 second-place prizes. What is the expected value of participating in this lottery?
When flipping a coin 10 times, there is an equal probability of flipping heads

Sally has 3 statistics tests. She has a probability of 75% of passing the first one. If she passes it, she has the probability of 75% of passing the second one. If she fails, she has a 25% chance of passing the second one. If she passes the second one, she has a probability of 90% of passing the third one, and if she fails the second, she has a 10% chance of passing the third. If she must pass 2 of the 3 tests to pass the class, what is the probability that she will pass the class?
Erin rolls a die six times and wants to determine the probability of getting a different value every time. Is this a binomial probability? If not, why?
choices: Yes, it is a binomial probability
No, there is not a fixed number of trials
No, there is not a definitive probability of success
No, the trials are not independent

questions.question: Jane rides her bike to school 60% of the time, and walks 40% of the time. If she makes it to school on time 90% of the time when she rides her bike and 70% of the time when she walks, what is the probability that she makes it to school on time on a randomly selected day?
Which value's removal would MOST change the mean of a given set?
choices: A value between the first and second quartile
A value between the second and third quartile
A value with a z-score of 0
